citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, several expired bottles of medication were observed commingled with other medications
routinely used in regulated animals. Expired medications observed included a parasiticide that expired in May 2023 and a
bottle of antibiotic medication that expired in December 2023.
Expired medications may not be safe or effective and are not an appropriate method for the treatment or prevention of
animal health issues. The facility must ensure that methods of treatment, including the medications maintained for use in
animals, are appropriate.
To be corrected by ensuring that all medications maintained for use in regulated animals are appropriate methods for the
treatment, control, or prevention of disease. Correct by September 1st, 2024.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult male rabbit was observed to be quiet and not moving around his enclosure at the time of inspection. When
stimulated, the animal was reluctant to rouse and appeared lethargic. There was patchy hair loss around the base of both
ears, and across the sides and tops of the shoulders, and patches of skin on both ears appear thickened and scaly. On
discussion with animal care staff, hair loss and a skin issue was identified approximately two weeks ago and the animal
was treated for ear mites. On discussion with the Attending Veterinarian, he was not notified of this ongoing health
problem or consulted to direct care.
In order to ensure that animals are provided with adequate veterinary care, problems of animal health, behavior, and well-
being must be conveyed accurately and in a timely manner to the attending veterinarian. Correct by July 27th, 2024.

A rabbit enclosure housing one rabbit was heavily soiled at the time of inspection. The absorbent pad used for bedding
material is brown and wet with an accumulation of waste and soiled hay on top. The rabbit must use this area of the
enclosure to access food and water receptacles. Primary enclosures housing rabbits must be cleaned frequently enough
to prevent the accumulation of excreta and other debris.
To be corrected by ensuring rabbit enclosures are cleaned with sufficient frequency to prevent the accumulation of
excreta and other debris. Correct by July 27th, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there is no written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being
of birds. Facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement, which
must be approved by the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by November 1st, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection, several expired bottles of medication were observed commingled with other medications 
routinely used in regulated animals. Expired medications observed included a parasiticide that expired in May 2023 and a 
bottle of antibiotic medication that expired in December 2023.  
 
Expired medications may not be safe or effective and are not an appropriate method for the treatment or prevention of 
animal health issues. The facility must ensure that methods of treatment, including the medications maintained for use in 
animals, are appropriate. 
 
To be corrected by ensuring that all medications maintained for use in regulated animals are appropriate methods for the 
treatment, control, or prevention of disease. Correct by September 1st, 2024. 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult male rabbit was observed to be quiet and not moving around his enclosure at the time of inspection. When 
stimulated, the animal was reluctant to rouse and appeared lethargic. There was patchy hair loss around the base of both 
ears, and across the sides and tops of the shoulders, and patches of skin on both ears appear thickened and scaly. On 
discussion with animal care staff, hair loss and a skin issue was identified approximately two weeks ago and the animal 
was treated for ear mites. On discussion with the Attending Veterinarian, he was not notified of this ongoing health 
problem or consulted to direct care. 
 
In order to ensure that animals are provided with adequate veterinary care, problems of animal health, behavior, and well-
being must be conveyed accurately and in a timely manner to the attending veterinarian. Correct by July 27th, 2024. 
3.56(a)(1)  Direct
   
Sanitation. 
A rabbit enclosure housing one rabbit was heavily soiled at the time of inspection. The absorbent pad used for bedding 
material is brown and wet with an accumulation of waste and soiled hay on top. The rabbit must use this area of the

enclosure to access food and water receptacles. Primary enclosures housing rabbits must be cleaned frequently enough 
to prevent the accumulation of excreta and other debris.  
 
To be corrected by ensuring rabbit enclosures are cleaned with sufficient frequency to prevent the accumulation of 
excreta and other debris. Correct by July 27th, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, there is no written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being 
of birds. Facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement, which 
must be approved by the attending veterinarian.  
 
To be corrected by November 1st, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
